educational_objective: Identify findings of acute aortic dissection on chest radiograph.
question_text: A 73-year-old woman is evaluated for acute-onset chest pain that radiates to her back. She has extensive cardiovascular disease and poorly controlled hypertension.Chest radiograph is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is acute aortic dissection (Option B). This patient's chest radiograph shows a widened superior mediastinum and a right pleural effusion consistent with aortic dissection, although these findings are not diagnostic. The diagnosis of aortic dissection can be established with transesophageal echocardiography, CT angiography, or MR angiography, all of which have similar sensitivity and specificity for acute thoracic aortic disease. Because of its wide availability and short image acquisition time, CT angiography is the primary diagnostic test for acute thoracic aortic disease.

figures.title: Chest Radiograph With Findings of Aortic Dissection
figures.short_title: stem CXR With Findings of Aortic Dissection
